journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A twin-rotor piston engine with annular connecting chambers

contrib-group.aff: College of Mechatronics Engineering and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China

author-notes.corresp: Hao Deng, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National University of Defense and Technology, Changsha 410073, Hunan Province, China. Email: aaron_dh@163.com

abstract.p: An effort in progress to develop a new twin-rotor piston engine is described. A proposition of sealing, which benefits from the conventional piston-cylinder structure is presented. A six-stroke twin-rotor piston engine, which is designed to have coolant intake and drain stroke is proposed. A differential velocity drive mechanism, which controls the rotors’ oscillation, is invented. The differential velocity drive mechanism utilizes novel kinematic design to completely eliminate inertial loads. The twin-rotor engine is expected to have three key technical advantages for attaining higher power density than any available piston engine: the first is symmetrical structure and well-balanced kinetics; the second is 16 or more power strokes per revolution of the output shaft and more than two symmetrical working chambers exporting power at any time; the third is performing the four-stroke cycle without using the valve mechanism.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The engine proposed in this article belongs to a category generally known as oscillatory rotating engine (ORE, also known as cat-and-mouse type engine). This type of engine was originally proposed by Bullington in 1926,1 and was developing rapidly in the period of 1930–1970.2,3 Since then, a high number of patents had been proposed. For example, the Tschudi engine4 and the Kauertz engine5 are the two most famous ones.

However, with the maturity of the conventional engine as well as the difficulty of developing a radically changed new engine, ORE was gradually abandoned in the 1970s. In the past decades, by realizing the crisis of global fuels shortage and the need of a future engine with higher power density, higher efficiency, people have been devoted to exploring or reconsidering other engine designs.6–8

ORE is regarded as one of the candidate devices to solve the crisis. Up-to-date technology also helps its improvement. Efforts to develop an innovative ORE are having been continuing in recent years, and many patents have been carried out. Librovich et al.9 and Librovich and Nowakowski10,11 proposed a novel rotary vane engine, which uses noncircular gears for torque transmission. Cheng et al.12,13 studied the eccentric circular–noncircular gear driving system of differential velocity pump. Liang14 proposed a rotary engine with two rotors and its design method. Shih15 analyzed the kinematics of the cycloidal internal combustion engine mechanism. Fong and Chang16 used the half-rounded gear to alternately lock and unlock the rotors of his rotary engine. Sakita17,18 described his cat-and-mouse type rotary engine and its performance evaluation. Kurisu19 utilized grooves and rods for power conveyance in his cat-and-mouse type rotary device. Wieslaw20 presented a new conception of oscillating engine. Additionally, as far as the author knows, two big progresses have been recently made. American inventor Morgado built a series of ORE protype (named after MYT Engine21). Russians manufactured an ORE, which is utilized in their first hybrid car (Yo-Mobile22).

It appears from the published literature that development of ORE is concentrating on its two mechanical systems. One is energy conversion system (ECS), and the other is differential velocity drive mechanism (DVDM).

The first aim of this article is to describe the old idea and to present an engine named by twin-rotor piston engine (TRPE). The second aim of this article is a proposition of sealing and cooling of ECS.23 Sealing of ECS have many difficulties, and its failure is the main reason why this type of engine has not been successfully built in the past. The third aim of this article is an introduction of a totally balanced DVDM.24 To the best of the author’s knowledge, the available types of DVDM include geared-linkage mechanism, elliptical gear system, half-rounded gear system, ratchet mechanism, etc. The poor design of DVDM is also the main reason for the failure of this type of engine.

sec.title: ECS of TRPE
sec.p: The concept of TRPE is generically related to conventional piston machines. For this reason, all the advances in reciprocating and rotary piston machines, including those of fuel consumption, exhaust, sealing technology and much more, could be utilized in TRPE.

sec.title: Configuration of ECS
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, ECS has two identical opposed rotors, the former rotor and the latter rotor. Both rotors are intersected mounted on the output shaft and enclosed in a stationary ECS housing. Each rotor has a number of vane pistons radially attached to the rotor hub. In general, assuming the number is N (N is a natural number). N vane pistons extend the full width of the housing, and divide the ECS housing into 2 N annular connecting working chambers. Each of the working chambers is located between a vane piston on the former rotor and its adjacent vane piston on the latter rotor. Such that at any one time, one set of N separated working chambers are close together while the other set of N separated working chambers are wide apart. Figure 1.
Configuration of a ECS with N vane pistons (N = 4).
ECS: energy conversion system.

In the case of the spark ignition engine, the two rotors are moved by an expanding ignited gas, and rotate with oscillating rotary movement in the same direction controlled by DVDM. One oscillation of a rotor is defined as the course of the angular velocity of the rotor reaching its maximum from minimum and then back to minimum. In order to make sure all intake ports and exhaust ports be fixed at a certain position of the housing and sufficiently utilize oscillations of the rotors, the number of oscillations per revolution of the rotor should also be equal to the number of vane pistons (N). Accordingly, the configuration of the ECS housing should include N/2 ignition devices, N/2 intake ports, N/2 exhaust ports. Each stroke is commenced or completed while any working chamber travels close to the ports.

The basic concept of TRPE is very similar to Wankel engine. Wankel engine25 performs the four-stroke cycle engine without using the valve mechanism and has one power stroke per revolution of the output shaft, as in the case of a two-stroke reciprocating engine. For above reasons, both Wankel engine and the two-stroke reciprocating engine have the superb features of light weight, compactness. So the engines with more power strokes per revolution of the output shaft may be able to generate higher power-to-weight ratio than conventional engines. In this study, TRPE, like the Wankel engine, also exhibits these characteristics.

Table 1 shows comparison of conventional L4 engine, Wankel engine and TRPE with 4, 6, 8 vane pistons (named as TRPE-4, TPPE-6 and TPPE-8 respectively). Comparing L4 with TRPE-4 as an example, on the one hand, both of them have the same four working chambers. On the other hand, TRPE-4 has 16 power strokes per revolution of the output shaft, while L4 has only 2 power strokes. Moreover, in TRPE-4, the respective ones of the four cycles are carried out simultaneously in diametrically opposed chambers. That is, the operations on one side of the engine are duplicated on the other side of the engine. This design provides a balance pressure forces within the eight working chambers of the engine. In all, TRPE has the potential of higher power density due to multiple utilization of work space and higher uniformity of torque due to more than two symmetrical working chamber exporting power at any time. Table 1.
Comparison of conventional L4 engine, Wankel engine and TRPEs.
Number of working chambers Number of power strokes per revolution of the output shaft Number of working chamber in combustion at any time
L4 4 2 1
Wankel 3 1 1
TRPE-4 4 16 2
TRPE-6 6 36 3
TRPE-8 8 64 4
TRPEs: twin-rotor piston engines.

sec.title: Motion characteristics of the rotors
sec.p:
Generally two rotors (each including a set of vane pistons) are used, geared to move in a fixed relationship as they rotate around the housing. As shown in Figures 2 and 3, θY(t) is the angular position of the former rotor; θL(t) is the angular position of the latter rotor; θ(t) is the angular position of the output shaft; δ(t) is the relative angle between the two adjacent vane pistons, Assuming the span angle of each vane piston, β, is the same, so δ(t) can be expressed as (1)δ(t)=θY(t)-θL(t)-β Figure 2.
Relation of angular position between the former rotor and the latter rotor.
Figure 3.
ECS (N = 4) at the time when the working chambers reaches their extreme value: (a) ECS at θ(t)=π/N; (b) ECS at θ(t)=2π/N.
ECS: energy conversion system.
In addition, there always exists an equation (2)N(2β+δmin+δmax)=2π where δmax and δmin are the maximum and minimum of δ.

While current technologies adapt combustion processes to engine design, the design of TRPE tends to adapt the engine design to combustion processes. Thus, δ(t) is designed to improve combustion performance. With equation (1), the relation between θY(t) and θL(t) is also obtained as follows (3)θY(t)-θL(t)=f(t) where f is assumed to be a known function derived from a design of the engine’s advance combustion processes, t is the time.
According to the fact that the two vane pistons can approach each other but not closer than a positive angle δmin, so the minimum and the maximum of f can be expressed as (4){fmin=β+δminfmax=β+δmax

As mentioned above, the number of oscillations per revolution of the rotor should be equal to N. For simplicity, assuming f(t) is a sinusoidal function with respect to θ(t). Using equations (2) and (4), expression of the function f is as follows (5)f(θ)=δmax-δmin2sin(Nθ+ϕ)+πN where ϕ is a phase angle which is determined by parameters of the respective DVDM.

Figure 2 shows relation of angular position between the former rotor and the latter rotor. Two lines in Figure 2 are determined by the equations as follows (6)L1:θY(θL)=θL(t)+β+δmin (7)L2:θY(θL)=θL(t)+β+δmax

Figures 1 and 3 show three moments when volume of working chambers denoted by odd number is at its minimum, maximum and then minimum in succession. Assuming the DVDM can assure the rotor rotate one revolution per revolution of the output shaft, then, the output shaft angle for max/min volume of combustion chamber, denoted by θm, can be expressed as (8)θm=kπN where k is an arbitrary integer number.

Assuming the output shaft rotates with a constant speed (ω0). δ(t) could also be expressed as (9)δ(t)=f(t)-β=∫θmθ(t)(ωY(t)-ωL(t))dθ(t)/ω0 where ωY(t) is the angular velocity of the former rotor, ωL(t) is the angular velocity of the latter rotor.

Figure 1 also shows the moment at θ(t)=0. Comparing it with Figure 3(a) and (b), every time the output shaft rotate an angle of π/N, vane pistons of one rotor moves to the previous position of vane pistons of the other rotor. For example, as the output shaft rotate from 0 to π/N, vane piston L1 gradually occupies the position of vane piston Y1, and vane piston Y2 gradually occupies the position of vane piston L1. So the former rotor rotates an angle of β+δmax, and the latter rotor rotates an angle of β+δmin, which can be expressed as (10){β+δmax=∫0π/N(ωY(t)/ω0)dθ(t)β+δmin=∫0π/N(ωL(t)/ω0)dθ(t) with equations (10) and (2), it is easily concluded that (11){∫0π/N(ωY(t)-ωL(t))dθ(t)/ω0=δmax-δmin∫0π/N(ωY(t)+ωL(t))dθ(t)/ω0=2πN

So, in each output shaft’s rotation of π/N, the summation of the angles covered by the two rotors is always equal to 2π/N. In addition, the two rotors rotate the above two predetermined angles alternately, i.e. as the output shaft rotate from π/N to 2π/N, the former rotor rotates an angle of β+δmin, and the latter rotor rotates an angle of β+δmax.

sec.title: Power density
sec.p:
As mentioned above, for the ECS with N vane pistons per rotor, DVDM should provide N oscillations on the rotors’ speed per rotation of the output shaft. Figure 4 shows an example of angular velocity of the former rotor and the latter rotor. ωY(t) is the angular velocity of the former rotor; ωL(t) is the angular velocity of the latter rotor; ωr(t) is the relative angular velocity between the two rotors, and is equal to ωY(t)-ωL(t). ωY(t), ωL(t) and ωr(t) have the same period of 2π/N. The former rotor rotates at a faster speed than the latter rotor during the compression and exhaust strokes of the working chambers denoted by odd number, and the former rotor rotates at a slower speed than the latter rotor during the combustion and intake strokes of these working chambers. Figure 4.
Relation of angular velocity between the former rotor and the latter rotor (N = 4).

As one oscillation means the combination of one contraction and one expansion stroke for each working chamber, in one revolution of the output shaft, each of 2 N working chambers completes N/2 power strokes. Thus, the number of power strokes per revolution of the output shaft, C, can be expressed as (12)C=N2

So the engine fires N2 times on one rotation of the output shaft, making it equivalent to a 2N2-cylinder, four-stroke engine. Listed in Table 2 are the sequence of the four strokes within combustion chambers of the TRPE. When the volume of the working chambers denoted by odd number is synchronous expanded, the volume of the working chambers denoted by even number is synchronous contracted and vice versa. The respective ones of the four cycles are carried out simultaneously in each N/2 spaced working chambers. Table 2.
Working cycle of the TRPE.
0 ~π/N π/N ~2π/N … (2π-2π/N) ~2π (2π-π/N) ~2π
I Compression Power … exhaust Intake
II Intake Compression … Power exhaust
III Exhaust Intake … Compression Power
IV Power exhaust … Intake Compression
V Compression Power … exhaust Intake
VI Intake Compression … Power exhaust
VII Exhaust Intake … Compression Power
VIII Power exhaust … Intake Compression
… … … … … …
TRPEs: twin-rotor piston engines.

Both of the front and back surfaces of the vane pistons are used for operation strokes, just like the double internal combustion engine, thereby achieving compact size and high engine efficiency. So due to multiple utilization of the working space of the ECS housing, the engine’s design not only provides a balance pressure forces but also increases the power density of the engine.

sec.title: Sealing of ECS
sec.p:
As far as the author knows, sealing of the ECS parts, especially the contact face between the two rotors are still difficult to now. As shown in Figure 5(a) and (b), two proposition of the rotors are presented. Compared to Figure 1, they are changed a lot in order to utilize the mature sealing technology that proven to be reliable in the current reciprocating piston–cylinder structure. Figure 5.
Two proposition of the rotors’ structure (N = 4). Structure of the former rotor: (a) one-part type, (b) combined type.

Figure 5(a) shows a one-part type of the former rotor. The latter rotor have the same structure with the former rotor. Each rotor comprises a rotor hub, N sysmetrically positioned vanes and their adherent pistons. The piston rings are laid in piston grooves which are similar to that used in the conventional reciprocating engines. Each vane on one rotor is machined a hole which received a piston on the other rotor, i.e. vane holes on one rotor and its respective pistons on the other rotor together forms 2 N working chambers. The disadvantage of this proposition is that the shape of the vane holes and pistons are difficult to form with an economical manufacture.

Figure 5(b) shows a combined type of the former rotor. The latter rotor also have the same structure with the former rotor. Different with the rotor in Figure 5(a), the pistons are connected with its vanes by connecting rods. The center line of the vane hole or the piston could be designed to be a straight line. The outer surfaces of the pistons or the vane holes are formed to be in form of a basically simple perfect circle, and thus the working accuracy can be easily enhanced in machining. So the advantage is that all the parts of the rotors can be easily manufactured, and the disadvantage is its complexity.

sec.title: Cooling of ECS
sec.p:
As we know, in an explosive combustion engine, especially for TRPE with high power density, a large amount of heat is generated and requires particular cooling. In order to achieve higher cooling performance by utilizing heat of vaporization, a six-stroke TRPE idea26 is introduced. As shown in Figure 6, TRPE is designed to have cooling ports in its housing. The engine’s operation is assumed to be associated with six strokes, i.e. gas intake, compression, combustion, gas exhaust, coolant intake and coolant drain. So in this proposition of TRPE, N should be a multiple of 3. Accordingly, the configuration of the ECS housing should include N/3 ignition devices, N/3 intake ports, N/3 exhaust ports, N/3 cooling areas. C is equal to 2N2/3. Figure 6.
A proposition of cooling ECS (N = 3).
ECS: energy conversion system.

Thus, on one hand, the rotors and the vane pistons can be appropriately cooled by a direct contact with a coolant. On the other hand, if necessary, the engine’s efficiency could be improved by employing two power strokes, given by fuel–air mixture and coolant converted to steam. For reducing thermal damage or thermal deformation, a low thermal-conductivity material, such as ceramic, should be applied to the rotors and the housing.

sec.title: Configuration of DVDM
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 7, a DVDM is designed which can restrict the two rotors to rotate with a speed pattern shown in Figure 4. The DVDM is a totally balanced mechanism, which consists of a stationary cam, an output stick (BB′), two rockers (the former rocker CC′ and the latter rocker AA′), two sliders (B and B′), four connecting rods (AB, BC, AB′, BC′), and a stationary DVDM housing. The DVDM housing is co-axial with and affixed to the ECS housing. Figure 7.
Configuration of a DVDM with N vane pistons (N = 4).
DVDM: differential velocity drive mechanism.

The output shaft is fixed to the output stick. As the output shaft rotates with a constant speed, the sliders move constrained by the output stick and the curved groove on the cam simultaneously, i.e. it will rotate about and move toward and away from the center (O) alternately. The motion of the sliders creates the periodic oscillation of the relative angular velocity between the former rocker and the latter rocker. As the former rotor is rigidly connected to the former rocker, and the latter rotor is rigidly connected to the latter rocker, the rotors are constrained to move with the same variable oscillatory rotation at a different pace.

sec.title: Parametric design of DVDM
sec.p:
For symmetry, there are two valid assumptions: (a) All connecting rods have the same length. (b) The length of the former rocker is the same as that of the latter rocker, and two times the length of connecting rods. As shown in Figure 8, l is the length of connecting rods; ρ(t) is defined as the distance from the rotation axis of the output shaft (O) to the joint center of the slider (B); the length of connecting rods;θ(t) is the angular position of the output stick (also the output shaft); θ1(t) is the angular position of the former rocker; θ2(t) is the angular position of the latter rocker. As the rockers are fixed on their respective rotors, so (13)θ1(t)-θ2(t)=θY(t)-θL(t)+θconst where the value of θconst determines the installation angle between the rockers and the rotors. Figure 8.
DVDM (N = 4) at the time when the working chambers reaches their extreme value.
DVDM: differential velocity drive mechanism.

g(θ) is defined as the relative angle between the former rocker and the latter rocker, i.e. g(θ)=θ1-θ2. Based on the assumption that f is a sinusoidal function with respect to θ, and with equations (3), (5) and (13), g(θ) can be expressed as (14)g(θ)=δmax-δmin2sin(Nθ+ϕ)+πN+θconst

Assuming g(θ) reaches its minimum at θ=0, then ϕ=-π/2. The amplitude of g(θ), Δ, which is equal to (δmax-δmin)/2, is a constant. The average of g(θ), g¯, which is equal to (π/N+θconst), is an unknown parameter. Then in the course of variation g(θ) from its minimum to its maximum, power (W) generated by the force (F) acting on a rocker from a connecting rod can be expressed as (15)W(g,g¯)=∫g¯-Δ2g¯+Δ2F(g)lsin(g)dg
Furthermore, by partial differentiating (15) (16)∂W∂g¯=F(g¯+Δ2)sin(g¯+Δ2)l -F(g¯-Δ2)sin(g¯-Δ2)l

For simplicity, assuming F(g¯+Δ/2)=F(g¯-Δ/2), so when g¯=π/2, ∂W/∂g¯=0. Thus, the average of g(θ) is designed to be π/2 for an optimized force transmission. Figures 7 and 8 show the two moments when working chambers reach their minimum or maximum. So (17)θconst=π2-πN
As θ1=θ+g(θ)/2, θ2=θ-g(θ)/2, then, θ1 and θ2 can be expressed as (18){θ1(θ)=π4+θ+δmax-δmin4sin(Nθ-π2)θ2(θ)=-π4+θ-δmax-δmin4sin(Nθ-π2)
With equations (14) and (17), based the law of cosine, ρ(θ) is obtained as (19)ρ(θ)=2lcos[δmax-δmin4sin(Nθ-π2)+π4]
On the other hand, compression ratio of the TRPE, ɛ, can be expressed as (20)ɛ=δmaxδmin
So if the compression ratio is given, then (21){δmax=2ɛ(π-Nβ)N(ɛ+1)δmin=2(π-Nβ)N(ɛ+1)

sec.title: Dynamic analysis of DVDM
sec.p: A simple dynamic model based on rigid body is constructed to simulate the dynamics of TRPE. (22){Jθ··=MSY+MSL+MkJYθ··Y=MYP+MYSJLθ··L=MLP+MLS where the dot in superscript denotes the time derivative, and MLP=-MYP (see Appendix).

The torque transmission between the output shaft and a rotor is based on power balance law (23){MSYθ·=kf1MYSθ·YMSLθ·=kf2MLSθ·L where kf1 and kf2 are the mechanical transmission efficiency which represent the excess power of the torque transmission due to friction, and for simplicity, kf1=kf2=kf.
Adiabatic approximation is used to computing the gas pressure in the combustion and compression working chamber at each output shaft angle. Thus (24)pVκ=R

Let Vj(θ) denote the volume of the j-th working chamber labeled between the vane pistons Yj and Lj and let Vj+1(θ) denote the volume of the (j + 1)-th working chamber labeled between the vane pistons Yj+1 and Lj. As an example, suppose that combustion takes places in the j-th working chamber while compression takes places in the (j + 1)-th working chamber. So (25){pig(θ)=pmax(VminVj(θ))κ=pmax(δminδj(θ))κpcp(θ)=pa(VmaxVj+1(θ))κ=pa(δmaxδj+1(θ))κ where κ is polytropic index, pmax is maximum pressure in working chamber, Vmin and Vmax are extreme values of working chamber volume, pa is atmospheric pressure.
It is assumed that the intake and output ports are quite large. Therefore, the difference among pressure in the intake chambers, exhaust chambers and ambient condition is small, so pin=pex=pa.
As shown in Figure 3, gas torque acting on the former rotor can be expressed as (26)MYP=Nh(d22-d12)16(pig-pcp)=Nh(d22-d12)16[pmax(δminδj)κ-pa(δmaxδj+1)κ]
Gas torque acting on the former rotor is equal to gas torque on the latter rotor by magnitude and opposite by direction, so (27)MYP=-MLP
External torque is chosen to be a viscous type load (28)Mk=-kdθ·
The coupling functions among the rotors and the output shaft can be expressed as (29){θY=fY(θ)θL=fL(θ)
It is a valid assumption that θ1 is equal to θY-θconst. Using equations (13) and (17), So (30){θY=fY(θ)=θ+δmax-δmin4sin(Nθ-π2)+πN-π4θL=fL(θ)=θ-δmax-δmin4sin(Nθ-π2)-π4
According to the principle of TRPE, there exists an equation, δj(t)+δj+1(t)=δmax+δmin. So using equations (1) and (30) (31){δj=δmax-δmin2sin(Nθ-π2)+πN-βδj+1=-δmax-δmin2sin(Nθ-π2)+δmax -δmin-πN+β

The time derivative of (30) yields (32){θ·Y(t)=fY'(θ)θ·(t)θ·L(t)=f'L(θ)θ·(t) where denotes differentiation, fY'(θ) is equal to 1+(δmax-δmin)Ncos(Nθ-π/2)/4, and fL'(θ) is equal to 1-(δmax-δmin)Ncos(Nθ-π/2)/4.
Furthermore by (33){θ··Y(t)=fY″(θ)θ·(t)2+fY'(θ)θ··(t)θ··L(t)=fL″(θ)θ·(t)2+fL'(θ)θ··(t) where fY″(θ) is equal to -(δmax-δmin)N2sin(Nθ-π/2)/4, and fL″(θ)=-fY″(θ).
Substituting (23)–(32) into (22) gives the output shaft rotary equation of motion in the form (34)[J+kfJY(fL'2-fY'2)]θ··(t)=kfJY(fY'fY″+fL'fL″)θ·(t)2 -kdθ·(t)+kfMYP[fL'-fY']

As a simulation example, values of parameters for simulation is setted as shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Values of parameters for simulation.
Variable Symbol Value
Rotational inertia of the output shaft (kg·m2) J 108
Rotational inertia of the the former/latter rotor (kg·m2) JY,JL 107
Mechanical transmission efficiency kf 0.9
Viscosity kd 0.3
Adiabatic constant κ 1.5
Atmospheric pressure (MPa) pa 0.1
Maximum pressure in working chamber (MPa) pmax 8.5
The number of vane pistons per rotor N 4
Compression ratio ɛ 10
the span angle of each vane piston (degree) β 25
Width of the working chamber (mm) h 100
External diameter of the vane piston (mm) d2 300
Internal diameter of the vane piston (mm) d1 150
The length of connecting rods l 100

As shown in Figure 9, the shape of the curve is mostly determined by the parameters N. N is equal to the number of petals on the curves, and it also means that the slider (B) will alternately move toward and then away from the center (O) N times as the output shaft rotates one revolution. Figure 9.
Cam groove curve for the TRPE with N = 4.
TRPE: twin-rotor piston engine.

Figure 10 shows a plot of angular position of the former and the latter rocker, versus the output shaft angle. It will be noted that the angular position of the rockers (also the rotors) varies with a cyclic rotary motion superposed on uniform rotary motion. The rockers continuously rotate in the same direction, and one revolution of the rockers is equivalent to one revolution of output crankshaft. Figure 10.
Angular positions of the former and the latter rocker vs the output crankshaft angle.

With the initial conditions θ(0)=0 and θ·(0)=10, the equation (31) yields numeric solutions. The simulation results shown in Figure 11 demonstrate that angular velocity of the output shaft has a oscillating behavior, but the magnitude of oscillations is small compare to the mean value. Figure 11.
The simulated rotary acceleration of the output shaft vs time.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A TRPE concept and propositions of its sealing, cooling have been presented. With the DVDM invented by the author, the engine holds out the promise of a greater power to weight ratio and a concomitant increase in efficiency.

TRPE is a machine for transforming stored chemical or physical energy into rotary motion. Obviously, its main mechanism especially discussed in this article can also be utilized for vacuum compressors or pumps. This new machine uses completely new principles of piston motion and of transmitting work from the piston to the driven shaft or from the drive shaft to the piston. So the TRPE technology offers a much greater flexibility for an exceptionally wide range of potential applications, including high power density engines for unmanned air vehicles (UAV), helicopters and fixed-wing aircrafts, vertical take off and landing (VTOL), large stationary and portable power generators, etc.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Defense Pre-research Foundation (Grant No: 7131109), China.

internal, External diameter of the vane piston (mm)
the relative angle between the former rocker and the latter rocker
rotational inertia of the output shaft (kg·m2)
rotational inertia of the the former, latter rotor (kg·m2)
